articles.headline: Elon Musk and Tesla Resolved One Issue. Now for the Rest.
articles.snippet: After deciding not to try to remove its shares from the market, the electric carmaker must focus on some stubborn challenges while facing new ones.
articles.abstract: After deciding not to try to remove its shares from the market, the electric carmaker must focus on some stubborn challenges while facing new ones.
articles.lead_paragraph: So Tesla is no longer seeking to go private. Now what?
articles.byline: By Neal E. Boudette and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: E-Sports World Is Rocked as Gunman ‘Clearly Targeted Other Gamers’
articles.snippet: A gunman who fatally shot two young men at a video gaming tournament in Florida appears to have targeted his fellow gamers, the authorities said.
articles.abstract: A gunman who fatally shot two young men at a video gaming tournament in Florida appears to have targeted his fellow gamers, the authorities said.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — The off-season had just ended. The competitors, the finest players of a football video game, had gathered on the riverfront in Jacksonville for two days of animated battle. The weekend’s tournament was their first sanctioned chance to show which game-winning moves of the “Madden” franchise they had unlocked.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder, Patricia Mazzei and Kevin Draper

articles.headline: The Trump Tax Cuts Were Supposed to Depress Housing Prices. They Haven’t.
articles.snippet: So far, economists see only faint effects of the new tax law in housing prices. The predicted carnage hasn’t materialized.
articles.abstract: So far, economists see only faint effects of the new tax law in housing prices. The predicted carnage hasn’t materialized.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It wasn’t supposed to take long for the Trump tax cuts to hobble housing prices, particularly in the high-tax, high-cost metro areas where the new law was poised to rip federal incentives to buy new homes.

articles.headline: North Carolina Is Ordered to Redraw Its Gerrymandered Congressional Map. Again.
articles.snippet: What happens next is unclear, but the case will likely be appealed to the Supreme Court, which has never ruled a partisan gerrymander to be unconstitutional.
articles.abstract: What happens next is unclear, but the case will likely be appealed to the Supreme Court, which has never ruled a partisan gerrymander to be unconstitutional.
articles.lead_paragraph: A panel of three federal judges again declared North Carolina’s congressional district map to be unconstitutional, ruling on Monday that it was gerrymandered to unfairly favor Republican candidates.
articles.byline: By Michael Wines and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: Letter Accusing Pope Leaves U.S. Catholics in Conflict
articles.snippet: As many conservatives support the former Vatican diplomat making explosive allegations against the pope, his U.S. allies have rushed to defend him.
articles.abstract: As many conservatives support the former Vatican diplomat making explosive allegations against the pope, his U.S. allies have rushed to defend him.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a remarkable break from the usual decorum among the bishops, American Catholic leaders are in open conflict over the explosive allegations from a former Vatican diplomat that Pope Francis knew about, and ignored, accusations of sexual abuse against a now-disgraced American cleric.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Dias and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: As Sears Withers, Its Former Stores Fuel a New Fortune
articles.snippet: An audacious feat of financial engineering is starting to pay off for a small group of wealthy investors who bet on redeveloping the retailer’s real estate.
articles.abstract: An audacious feat of financial engineering is starting to pay off for a small group of wealthy investors who bet on redeveloping the retailer’s real estate.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few blocks from the ocean, in the heart of Santa Monica, Calif., plans for “creative” offices are taking shape, tailored to the area’s burgeoning tech industry.

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Takes a (Careful) Step Toward Autonomous Flying
articles.snippet: A new flying ambulance service will use small helicopters outfitted with tech that could eventually let them fly without pilots.
articles.abstract: A new flying ambulance service will use small helicopters outfitted with tech that could eventually let them fly without pilots.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRACY, Calif. — Last week, at a tiny airport in the dusty flatlands east of San Francisco, a red-and-white helicopter lifted gently into the air, hovering a few feet over the tarmac. It looked like any other helicopter, except for the small black cube attached to its nose.
